{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3400871,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T02:15:00.143Z","cooked":"

So this year 2024, was my teams rookie year, and we had a kitbot, the laptop that came with the kitbot was genuinely the worst device I have ever experienced, and I am not doing that again. I have talked with my mentors and their exact words were “just under 2000$” for next years laptop (seems like a little much but I wont complain), so I was wondering what laptop we should get for programming, keep in mind I will likely be the only programmer next year so they like to spoil me. If it matters I program in Java.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":50,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T02:15:00.143Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3289,"reads":564,"readers_count":563,"score":16562.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467861,"topic_slug":"best-laptop-for-programming","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/best-laptop-for-programming/467861/1","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3400895,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T03:00:23.154Z","cooked":"

Dell Latitude 5000 5430 14" Rugged Notebook - Full HD - 1920 x 1080 - Intel Core i5 11th Gen i5-1145G7 Quad-core (4 Core) 2.60 GHz - 16 GB Total RAM - 512 GB SSD - Black https://a.co/d/0cbPmniJ my beloved

Lenovo’s Thinkpad line is also fairly well regarded. But honestly, I am a Dell rugged fan if you have the cash.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":50,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T03:06:41.304Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":520,"readers_count":519,"score":319.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467861,"topic_slug":"best-laptop-for-programming","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/best-laptop-for-programming/467861/3","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3400899,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T03:16:25.340Z","cooked":"

There’s a lot of good laptops

I’d get:
At least 16gb ram
At least 512gb storage
At least Core i5/Ryzen 5
16x10 screen preferred

I like Lenovos and dells. But honestly, any laptop over $1500 is going to be pretty decent

Consider getting 2 used over 1 new. That way you have a backup or one for another programmer. Some companies sell their old ones (2-4 years old) for 90% off

If it doesn’t need to also be the driver station, I would get the lowest level MacBook Air over any windows laptop.

Disagreed- official competition driver station laptop or not, I think a laptop specifically bought for programming must be able to run the driver station, which to my understanding a macbook wouldn’t. How are you supposed to test otherwise?

I use a dell g3 (it’s my computer, not the team coding computer) but wouldn’t recommend it, it’s been kinda flaky.

LHACK4142:

How are you supposed to test otherwise?

With the driver station laptop, which the driver station controllers are plugged into anyway (usually)

ArchdukeTim:

With the driver station laptop, which the driver station controllers are plugged into anyway (usually)

I guess that works, but I do like the convenience and simplicity of a programming laptop that can also run the DS. I can develop on just 1 computer and plug controllers into said computer.
In fairness, I haven’t used macbooks, so maybe there’s something really awesome about them I’m not aware of.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":50,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T15:47:34.668Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":333,"readers_count":332,"score":76.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467861,"topic_slug":"best-laptop-for-programming","display_username":"Pizzatc","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54022,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2659"},"post_url":"/t/best-laptop-for-programming/467861/11","custom_user_title":"2659","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401032,"name":"","username":"four","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T16:56:12.947Z","cooked":"
Chadfrom7226:

At least Core i5/Ryzen 5

In general this is good, but be careful to check the specific CPU model. For example, a Ryzen 5 2500u is a quad-core from 2017 that boosts to 3.6GHz while a modern Ryzen 5 8640u is a hexa-core boosting to 4.9 GHz. Also, for FRC purposes you will probably want to stick with AMD/Intel. Unlikely that a lot of FRC specific applications are going to be ported to ARM anytime soon.

Maybe look to have upgradability in the storage and memory as this will increase the device longevity. If you are buying used, either look for an SSD or have one to replace the hard drive.

Purely as a quality of life and practicality thing, consider the battery capacity. I have a Thinkpad T560 that has two batteries and it can last for many hours of work. All Thinkpads in the non-s T series TX4X-TX8X should have these. You can even buy additional external batteries and hotswap them if necessary. The drawback is that I do not think any modern machine has removable batteries so you trade performance for it.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":50,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T16:56:12.947Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":325,"readers_count":324,"score":130.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467861,"topic_slug":"best-laptop-for-programming","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60512,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work."},"post_url":"/t/best-laptop-for-programming/467861/12","custom_user_title":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401050,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T18:18:32.138Z","cooked":"
gerthworm:

Dell Latitude 5000 5430 14" Rugged Notebook - Full HD - 1920 x 1080 - Intel Core i5 11th Gen i5-1145G7 Quad-core (4 Core) 2.60 GHz - 16 GB Total RAM - 512 GB SSD - Black https://a.co/d/0cbPmniJ my beloved

Lenovo’s Thinkpad line is also fairly well regarded. But honestly, I am a Dell rugged fan if you have the cash.

Latitude Rugged is a beast for sure, but for the price of one of them new you could get four not-rugged Latitude 5430s used off eBay.

Put it this way: My employer is a state agency with dozens and dozens of field staff. We’re out in the middle of nowhere conducting inspections on scales, gas pumps, animal feed, and if you give us about a week and a half we’ll be doing all of our state’s restaurant and retail food inspections too. And we don’t issue rugged laptops because they don’t make economic sense.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":50,"updated_at":"2024-06-23T13:28:56.167Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":290,"readers_count":289,"score":203.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467861,"topic_slug":"best-laptop-for-programming","display_username":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":3095,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"says you should come to SCRIW in October"},"post_url":"/t/best-laptop-for-programming/467861/13","custom_user_title":"says you should come to SCRIW in October","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401052,"name":"Smtopps","username":"Smtopps","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/smtopps/{size}/166758_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T18:29:56.177Z","cooked":"

You have a pretty good budget to work with at $2000. Personally I’ve had a lot of bad experiences with dell. I’ve had several dell latitudes and I think they all had parts fall off or break with very little abuse. Recently someone bought our team a more recent 13" dell vostro laptop and I hate almost everything about from an engineering and design perspective. The worst part is when you open the screen the back of the laptop is supported by the screen which lifts the keyboard up. It feels weak though and with the chassis flex it doesn’t inspire confidence in durability. Also you should consider one with an Ethernet port and not a hinged Ethernet port.

Personally I own a Thinkpad P1 and the team uses a 2017 thinkpad x270 and both have been great. The x270 is built like a tank compared to the dell we have.

The Framework laptop 13 and laptop 16 lands well within your budget. Strong chance that will be my next laptop. You should be able to save money if you want to hunt for deals on memory and storage from amazon or newegg.

Our team bought a lenovo thinkpad last year and it’s been treating us pretty great. I would also like other people suggest avoiding dell as a manufacturer.

Aside from the performance spec recommendations from others i would also suggest looking for a laptop with

  • ethernet port
  • multiple usb ports
  • great battery life

Smtopps:

I’ve had several dell latitudes and I think they all had parts fall off or break with very little abuse. Recently someone bought our team a more recent 13" dell vostro laptop and I hate almost everything about from an engineering and design perspective.

What model of Latitude are you experiencing that on? Our experience hasn’t been completely airtight (one batch of 2-in-1 laptops proved pretty death-prone), but the mainline Latitudes I’d look at for FRC duty (since they’re the ones still packing Ethernet ports and such) tend to go the distance with us. Usually 5 years is standard for us when buying new at work; I’d expect to get at least 2-3 seasons out of a $300 off-lease unit.

Vostro is Dell’s “small business” line and completely separate. I agree there’s nothing of value there.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":50,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T19:38:39.427Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":247,"readers_count":246,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":467861,"topic_slug":"best-laptop-for-programming","display_username":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":3095,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"says you should come to SCRIW in October"},"post_url":"/t/best-laptop-for-programming/467861/17","custom_user_title":"says you should come to SCRIW in October","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401076,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T19:58:37.840Z","cooked":"

Personally, out of all laptops tried by our programming team, I liked LG Gram the most.

  1. Big screen is important. You really want to see as much code as you can. So, a minimum 16" screen would be a must, 17" is even better.

  2. 32Gb of RAM is important. You can get by with 16, but once you start opening multiple projects at the same time, the performance will go down the drain with less than that.

  3. Ability to support multiple monitors is important.
    Your programmers want to show the code to each other. Connecting another monitor to your laptop in a programming environment is a key. Yes, you can huddle around a smaller screen, but this impacts productivity.

  4. Stick to Intel CPUs. Yes, AMD works. However, if you deal with third-party software, stick to the “standard” to avoid any unexpected consequences. For that price you can easily get one with i7 CPU.

  5. Battery life is paramount. If you plan to use the same laptop as a driver station, make sure the battery lasts at least from the morning until lunch. People will forget to change it. That’s a fact. LG probably has the longest lasting battery (11 hrs or so).

  6. Get a laptop with metal covers. Team laptop will be scratched, occasionally dropped and generally needs to be a bit sturdy. Aluminum cover helps, and LG, again, fits the bill.

  7. Get a laptop with touchscreen. Yes, it’s not needed for the individual programming. But as a team exercise you want to be able to quickly point to something. And what better way to do so than using a touchscreen? As added benefit, you can use your custom dashboards where you can select things during matches without using the mouse. That’s much faster.

  8. Get a laptop with USB charger. If you forget your charger or lose it, you can easily find a third-party replacement if your laptop charges over USB.

  9. Get a laptop with decent screen resolution (but you do not necessarily need 4k). Intel built-in video cards provide decent performance for programming and simulation. No need to get fancy nvidia, as this will just drain the battery.

  10. Get a laptop with SSD (and not HDD). 1Tb should be plenty; 512Gb would be sufficient.

Costco runs decent sales on LG during any major holidays. I have one used by a college student for 2 years (CS major) and it’s going strong; no issues with it.

That was the laptops I got from state DoT. They were Latitude 5490 and just had keyboard adhesive covers and not rugged. They were a little worn from being field used but pretty good and I bought them off a govdeals auction for $170. That was a ridiculous good deal but there are still some good deals there in surplus auctions. If you have a few teams wanting laptops you might be able to buy a pallet full and split them. I’ve been looking again mainly for 5420 or similar to upgrade to.

If you go for a used laptop try to get one made in the past 3 years. Windows 10 goes end of support fall 2025. If the laptop you get isn’t windows 11 compatible, you’ll really only get a good year out of it. You can find windows 11 compatible computers from earlier than 2021 but it’s won’t be guaranteed.
